Text: And thank you for agreeing to moderate this debate this evening.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Thank you to Lynn University for welcoming us here.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And Mr. President, it's good to be with you again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We were together at a humorous event a little earlier, and it's nice to maybe funny this time, not on purpose.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is obviously an area of great concern to the entire world, and to America in particular, which is to see a -- a complete change in the -- the structure and the -- the environment in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: With the Arab Spring, came a great deal of hope that there would be a change towards more moderation, and opportunity for greater participation on the part of women in public life, and in economic life in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But instead, we've seen in nation after nation, a number of disturbing events.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Of course we see in Syria, 30,000 civilians having been killed by the military there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We see in -- in Libya, an attack apparently by, I think we know now, by terrorists of some kind against -- against our people there, four people dead.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our hearts and -- and minds go out to them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Mali has been taken over, the northern part of Mali by al-Qaeda type individuals.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have in -- in Egypt, a Muslim Brotherhood president.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so what we're seeing is a pretty dramatic reversal in the kind of hopes we had for that region.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Of course the greatest threat of all is Iran, four years closer to a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and we're going to have to recognize that we have to do as the president has done.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I congratulate him on -- on taking out Osama bin Laden and going after the leadership in al-Qaeda.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But we can't kill our way out of this mess.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're going to have to put in place a very comprehensive and robust strategy to help the -- the world of Islam and other parts of the world, reject this radical violent extremism, which is -- it's certainly not on the run.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a group that is now involved in 10 or 12 countries, and it presents an enormous threat to our friends, to the world, to America, long term, and we must have a comprehensive strategy to help reject this kind of extremism.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, my first job as commander in chief, Bob, is to keep the American people safe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's what we've done over the last four years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We ended the war in Iraq, refocused our attention on those who actually killed us on 9/11.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, Al Qaeda's core leadership has been decimated.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In addition, we're now able to transition out of Afghanistan in a responsible way, making sure that Afghans take responsibility for their own security.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that allows us also to rebuild alliances and make friends around the world to combat future threats.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now with respect to Libya, as I indicated in the last debate, when we received that phone call, I immediately made sure that, number one, that we did everything we could to secure those Americans who were still in harm's way; number two, that we would investigate exactly what happened, and number three, most importantly, that we would go after those who killed Americans and we would bring them to justice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's exactly what we're going to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I think it's important to step back and think about what happened in Libya.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Keep in mind that I and Americans took leadership in organizing an international coalition that made sure that we were able to, without putting troops on the ground at the cost of less than what we spent in two weeks in Iraq, liberate a country that had been under the yoke of dictatorship for 40 years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Got rid of a despot who had killed Americans and as a consequence, despite this tragedy, you had tens of thousands of Libyans after the events in Benghazi marching and saying America is our friend.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now that represents the opportunity we have to take advantage of.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, Governor Romney, I'm glad that you agree that we have been successful in going after Al Qaida, but I have to tell you that, you know, your strategy previously has been one that has been all over the map and is not designed to keep Americans safe or to build on the opportunities that exist in the Middle East.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, my strategy is pretty straightforward, which is to go after the bad guys, to make sure we do our very best to interrupt them, to -- to kill them, to take them out of the picture.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But my strategy is broader than that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's -- that's important, of course.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the key that we're going to have to pursue is a -- is a pathway to get the Muslim world to be able to reject extremism on its own.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't want another Iraq, we don't want another Afghanistan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's not the right course for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The right course for us is to make sure that we go after the -- the people who are leaders of these various anti-American groups and these -- these jihadists, but also help the Muslim world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And how do we do that?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: A group of Arab scholars came together, organized by the U.N., to look at how we can help the -- the world reject these -- these terrorists.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the answer they came up with was this:
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We should key our foreign aid, our direct foreign investment, and that of our friends, we should coordinate it to make sure that we -- we push back and give them more economic development.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number four, the rule of law.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to help these nations create civil societies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But what's been happening over the last couple of years is, as we've watched this tumult in the Middle East, this rising tide of chaos occur, you see Al Qaida rushing in, you see other jihadist groups rushing in.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and they're throughout many nations in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's wonderful that Libya seems to be making some progress, despite this terrible tragedy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But next door, of course, we have Egypt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Libya's 6 million population; Egypt, 80 million population.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want -- we want to make sure that we're seeing progress throughout the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: With Mali now having North Mali taken over by Al Qaida; with Syria having Assad continuing to -- to kill, to murder his own people, this is a region in tumult.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And, of course, Iran on the path to a nuclear weapon, we've got real (inaudible).
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor Romney, I'm glad that you recognize that Al Qaida is a threat, because a few months ago when you were asked what's the biggest geopolitical threat facing America, you said Russia, not Al Qaida; you said Russia, in the 1980s, they're now calling to ask for their foreign policy back because, you know, the Cold War's been over for 20 years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But Governor, when it comes to our foreign policy, you seem to want to import the foreign policies of the 1980s, just like the social policies of the 1950s and the economic policies of the 1920s.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You say that you're not interested in duplicating what happened in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But just a few weeks ago, you said you think we should have more troops in Iraq right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the -- the challenge we have -- I know you haven't been in a position to actually execute foreign policy -- but every time you've offered an opinion, you've been wrong.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said we should have gone into Iraq, despite that fact that there were no weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said that we should still have troops in Iraq to this day.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You indicated that we shouldn't be passing nuclear treaties with Russia despite the fact that 71 senators, Democrats and Republicans, voted for it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said that, first, we should not have a timeline in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Then you said we should.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now you say maybe or it depends, which means not only were you wrong, but you were also confusing in sending mixed messages both to our troops and our allies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, what -- what we need to do with respect to the Middle East is strong, steady leadership, not wrong and reckless leadership that is all over the map.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And unfortunately, that's the kind of opinions that you've offered throughout this campaign, and it is not a recipe for American strength, or keeping America safe over the long haul.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, of course I don't concur with what the president said about my own record and the things that I've said.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They don't happen to be accurate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But -- but I can say this, that we're talking about the Middle East and how to help the Middle East reject the kind of terrorism we're seeing, and the rising tide of tumult and -- and confusion.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and attacking me is not an agenda.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Attacking me is not talking about how we're going to deal with the challenges that exist in the Middle East, and take advantage of the opportunity there, and stem the tide of this violence.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, Russia I indicated is a geopolitical foe.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's a geopolitical foe, and I said in the same -- in the same paragraph I said, and Iran is the greatest national security threat we face.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Russia does continue to battle us in the U.N. time and time again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I have clear eyes on this.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm not going to wear rose-colored glasses when it comes to Russia, or Mr. Putin.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I'm certainly not going to say to him, I'll give you more flexibility after the election.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: After the election, he'll get more backbone.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, with regards to Iraq, you and I agreed I believe that there should be a status of forces agreement.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You didn't want a status of...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What I would not have had done was left 10,000 troops in Iraq that would tie us down.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that certainly would not help us in the Middle East.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm sorry, you actually -- there was a -- there was an effort on the part of the president to have a status of forces agreement, and I concurred in that, and said that we should have some number of troops that stayed on.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That was something I concurred with...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That was my posture as well.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You thought it should have been 5,000 troops...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I thought there should have been more troops, but you know what?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The answer was we got...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... no troops through whatsoever.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This was just a few weeks ago that you indicated that we should still have troops in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ...that's a -- I indicated...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ...I indicated that you failed to put in place a status...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ...of forces agreement at the end of the conflict that existed.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor -- here -- here's -- here's one thing...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ...here's one thing I've learned as commander in chief.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You've got to be clear, both to our allies and our enemies, about where you stand and what you mean.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You just gave a speech a few weeks ago in which you said we should still have troops in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is not a recipe for making sure that we are taking advantage of the opportunities and meeting the challenges of the Middle East.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, it is absolutely true that we cannot just meet these challenges militarily.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so what I've done throughout my presidency and will continue to do is, number one, make sure that these countries are supporting our counterterrorism efforts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, make sure that they are standing by our interests in Israel's security, because it is a true friend and our greatest ally in the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number three, we do have to make sure that we're protecting religious minorities and women because these countries can't develop unless all the population, not just half of it, is developing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number four, we do have to develop their economic -- their economic capabilities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But number five, the other thing that we have to do is recognize that we can't continue to do nation building in these regions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Part of American leadership is making sure that we're doing nation building here at home.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That will help us maintain the kind of American leadership that we need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we've done is organize the international community, saying Assad has to go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've mobilized sanctions against that government.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have made sure that they are isolated.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have provided humanitarian assistance and we are helping the opposition organize, and we're particularly interested in making sure that we're mobilizing the moderate forces inside of Syria.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But ultimately, Syrians are going to have to determine their own future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so everything we're doing, we're doing in consultation with our partners in the region, including Israel which obviously has a huge interest in seeing what happens in Syria; coordinating with Turkey and other countries in the region that have a great interest in this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This -- what we're seeing taking place in Syria is heartbreaking, and that's why we are going to do everything we can to make sure that we are helping the opposition.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we also have to recognize that, you know, for us to get more entangled militarily in Syria is a serious step, and we have to do so making absolutely certain that we know who we are helping; that we're not putting arms in the hands of folks who eventually could turn them against us or allies in the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I am confident that Assad's days are numbered.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what we can't do is to simply suggest that, as Governor Romney at times has suggested, that giving heavy weapons, for example, to the Syrian opposition is a simple proposition that would lead us to be safer over the long term.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, let's step back and talk about what's happening in Syria and how important it is.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, 30,000 people being killed by their government is a humanitarian disaster.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Secondly, Syria is an opportunity for us because Syria plays an important role in the Middle East, particularly right now.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Syria is Iran's only ally in the Arab world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's their route to the sea.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's the route for them to arm Hezbollah in Lebanon, which threatens, of course, our ally, Israel.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so seeing Syria remove Assad is a very high priority for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, seeing a -- a replacement government being responsible people is critical for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And finally, we don't want to have military involvement there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't want to get drawn into a military conflict.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so the right course for us, is working through our partners and with our own resources, to identify responsible parties within Syria, organize them, bring them together in a -- in a form of -- if not government, a form of -- of -- of council that can take the lead in Syria.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then make sure they have the arms necessary to defend themselves.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We do need to make sure that they don't have arms that get into the -- the wrong hands.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Those arms could be used to hurt us down the road.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to make sure as well that we coordinate this effort with our allies, and particularly with -- with Israel.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the Saudi's and the Qatari, and -- and the Turks are all very concerned about this.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're willing to work with us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to have a very effective leadership effort in Syria, making sure that the -- the insurgent there are armed and that the insurgents that become armed, are people who will be the responsible parties.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Recognize -- I believe that Assad must go.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I believe he will go.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I believe -- we want to make sure that we have the relationships of friendship with the people that take his place, steps that in the years to come we see Syria as a -- as a friend, and Syria as a responsible party in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This -- this is a critical opportunity for America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what I'm afraid of is we've watched over the past year or so, first the president saying, well we'll let the U.N. deal with it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And Assad -- excuse me, Kofi Annan came in and said we're going to try to have a ceasefire.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Then it went to the Russians and said, let's see if you can do something.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We are playing the leadership role.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We organized the Friends of Syria.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are mobilizing humanitarian support, and support for the opposition.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But going back to Libya -- because this is an example of how we make choices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When we went in to Libya, and we were able to immediately stop the massacre there, because of the unique circumstances and the coalition that we had helped to organize.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We also had to make sure that Moammar Gadhafi didn't stay there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And to the governor's credit, you supported us going into Libya and the coalition that we organized.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But when it came time to making sure that Gadhafi did not stay in power, that he was captured, Governor, your suggestion was that this was mission creep, that this was mission muddle.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so we were going to make sure that we finished the job.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's part of the reason why the Libyans stand with us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we did so in a careful, thoughtful way, making certain that we knew who we were dealing with, that those forces of moderation on the ground were ones that we could work with, and we have to take the same kind of steady, thoughtful leadership when it comes to Syria.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's exactly what we're doing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I don't want to have our military involved in Syria.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't think there is a necessity to put our military in Syria at this stage.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't anticipate that in the future.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As I indicated, our objectives are to replace Assad and to have in place a new government which is friendly to us, a responsible government, if possible.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I want to make sure they get armed and they have the arms necessary to defend themselves, but also to remove -- to remove Assad.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I do not want to see a military involvement on the part of our -- of our troops.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And this isn't -- this isn't going to be necessary.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We -- we have, with our partners in the region, we have sufficient resources to support those groups.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But look, this has been going on for a year.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a time -- this should have been a time for American leadership.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We should have taken a leading role, not militarily, but a leading role organizationally, governmentally to bring together the parties; to find responsible parties.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As you hear from intelligence sources even today, the -- the insurgents are highly disparate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They haven't formed a unity group, a council of some kind.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: America can help that happen.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And we need to make sure they have the arms they need to carry out the very important role which is getting rid of Assad.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, I'll -- I'll be very quick.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What you just heard Governor Romney said is he doesn't have different ideas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's because we're doing exactly what we should be doing to try to promote a moderate Syrian leadership and a -- an effective transition so that we get Assad out.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the kind of leadership we've shown.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the kind of leadership we'll continue to show.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No, I don't, because I think that America has to stand with democracy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The notion that we would have tanks run over those young people who were in Tahrir Square, that is not the kind of American leadership that John F. Kennedy talked about 50 years ago.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what I've also said is that now that you have a democratically elected government in Egypt, that they have to make sure that they take responsibility for protecting religious minorities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we have put significant pressure on them to make sure they're doing that; to recognize the rights of women, which is critical throughout the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: These countries can't develop if young women are not given the kind of education that they need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have to abide by their treaty with Israel.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is a red line for us, because not only is Israel's security at stake, but our security is at stake if that unravels.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have to make sure that they're cooperating with us when it comes to counterterrorism.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we will help them with respect to developing their own economy, because ultimately what's going to make the Egyptian revolution successful for the people of Egypt, but also for the world, is if those young people who gathered there are seeing opportunities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Their aspirations are similar to young people's here.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They want jobs, they want to be able to make sure their kids are going to a good school.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They want to make sure that they have a roof over their heads and that they have the prospects of a better life in the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so one of the things that we've been doing is, is, for example, organizing entrepreneurship conferences with these Egyptians to give them a sense of how they can start rebuilding their economy in a way that's noncorrupt, that's transparent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what is also important for us to understand is, is that for America to be successful in this region there's some things that we're going to have to do here at home as well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, one of the challenges over the last decade is we've done experiments in nation building in places like Iraq and Afghanistan and we've neglected, for example, developing our own economy, our own energy sectors, our own education system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it's very hard for us to project leadership around the world when we're not doing what we need to do...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe, as the president indicated, and said at the time that I supported his -- his action there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I wish that, looking back at the beginning of the president's term and even further back than that, that we'd have recognized that there was a growing energy and passion for freedom in that part of the world, and that we would have worked more aggressively with our friend and with other friends in the region to have them make the transition towards a more representative form of government, such that it didn't explode in the way that it did.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But once it exploded, I felt the same as the president did, which is these freedom voices and the streets of Egypt, where the people who were speaking of our principles and the President Mubarak had done things which were unimaginable and the idea of him crushing his people was not something that we could possibly support.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me step back and talk about what I think our mission has to be in the Middle East and even more broadly, because our purpose is to make sure the world is more -- is peaceful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want a peaceful planet.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want people to be able to enjoy their lives and know they're going to have a bright and prosperous future, not be at war.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the mantle of leadership for the -- promoting the principles of peace has fallen to America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We didn't ask for it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But it's an honor that we have it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But for us to be able to promote those principles of peace requires us to be strong.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that begins with a strong economy here at home.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Unfortunately, the economy is not stronger.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Former chief of the -- Joint Chiefs of Staff said that -- Admiral Mullen said that our debt is the biggest national security threat we face.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This -- we have weakened our economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need a strong economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to have as well a strong military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our military is second to none in the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're blessed with terrific soldiers, and extraordinary technology and intelligence.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the idea of a trillion dollar in cuts through sequestration and budget cuts to the military would change that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to have strong allies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our association and connection with our allies is essential to America's strength.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're the great nation that has allies, 42 allies and friends around the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And if we're strong in each of those things, American influence will grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But unfortunately, in nowhere in the world is America's influence will grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But unfortunately, in -- nowhere in the world is America's influence greater today than it was four years ago.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that's because we've become weaker in each of those four...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well I -- I absolutely believe that America has a -- a responsibility, and the privilege of helping defend freedom and promote the principles that -- that make the world more peaceful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And those principles include human rights, human dignity, free enterprise, freedom of expression, elections.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Because when there are elections, people tend to vote for peace.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They don't vote for war.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So we want to promote those principles around the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We recognize that there are places of conflict in the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want to end those conflicts to the extent humanly possible.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But in order to be able to fulfill our role in the world, America must be strong.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And for that to happen, we have to strengthen our economy here at home.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't have 23 million people struggling to get a job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't have an economy that over the last three years keeps slowing down its growth rate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't have kids coming out of college, half of them can't find a job today, or a job that's commensurate with their college degree.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to get our economy going.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And our military, we've got to strengthen our military long-term.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't know what the world is going to throw at us down the road.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We -- we make decisions today in the military that -- that will confront challenges we can't imagine.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In the 2000 debates, there was no mention of terrorism, for instance.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And a year later, 9/11 happened.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So, we have to make decisions based upon uncertainty, and that means a strong military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will not cut our military budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to also stand by our allies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I -- I think the tension that existed between Israel and the United States was very unfortunate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think also that pulling our missile defense program out of Poland in the way we did was also unfortunate in terms of, if you will, disrupting the relationship in some ways that existed between us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then, of course, with regards to standing for our principles, when -- when the students took to the streets in Tehran and the people there protested, the Green Revolution occurred, for the president to be silent I thought was an enormous mistake.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to stand for our principles, stand for our allies, stand for a strong military and stand for a stronger economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: America remains the one indispensable nation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the world needs a strong America, and it is stronger now than when I came into office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because we ended the war in Iraq, we were able to refocus our attention on not only the terrorist threat, but also beginning a transition process in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It also allowed us to refocus on alliances and relationships that had been neglected for a decade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Governor Romney, our alliances have never been stronger, in Asia, in Europe, in Africa, with Israel, where we have unprecedented military and intelligence cooperation, including dealing with the Iranian threat.
Speaker: Barack Obama
